occurrences.line_text: Vpon a recluse Virgin to lay hold,
And droue them to recoile: but when againe
Made them recoile, and fly from dred decay,
Gan her recomfort from so sad affright,
And gan recomfort her in her rude wyse,
Her to recomfort, and accourage bold,
Ne to recomfort her at all preuayld;
Him to recomfort in his greatest care,
Him to recomfort with my companie.
Gan to recomfort her all that he might,
Gan him recomfort, and from ground to reare.
And to recomfort him, all comely meanes did frame.
He her gan to recomfort, all he might,
Whom to recomfort, all the meanes he wrought,
Thus as she her recomforted, she spyde,
And her recomforted the best he might,
Yet nould she be recomforted for nought,
That all the wretched world recomforteth againe.
But Calidore recomforting his griefe,
Restlesse, recomfortlesse, with heart deepe grieued,
And rule his people right, as he doth recommend.
Therefore her selfe she wholy recommended
His louely words her seemd due recompence
He shall you doe due recompence againe,
With recompence of euerlasting fame.
The recompence of their periured oth,
In equall ballance with due recompence,
She then in recompence of that great fauour,
That for such good him recompence with ill?
For recompence of all their former wrong:
Besides for recompence hereof, I shall
Deserued for their perils recompense.
And recompenst him with a better scorse:
She in regard thereof him recompenst
To rest themselues, and grace to reconcile.
Thus reconcilement was betweene them knit,
Faire Psyche to him lately reconcyld,
Them reconcyld againe, and to their homes did driue.
That for the present they were reconcyld,
And many Chroniclers, that can record
To be the record of his ruefull losse,
O heauie record of the good Redcrosse,
Here to record, ne much materiall:
But by record of antique times I find,
How many foundst thou such to put in thy record?
So oft as I this history record,
Let them record them, that are better skild,
He gan record the lamentable stowre,
Which he recorded still, as they did pas,
And old records from auncient times deriu'd,
Long had the Thames (as we in records reed)
And records of antiquitie appeare,
Or euer hope recouer her againe:
And to recouer right for such, as wrong did grieue.
And rest themselues for to recouer spirits spent.
Which neuer they recouer might againe;
Till I the conquest of my will recouer.
And ere he could recouer foot againe,
And least he should recouer foote againe,
At last when life recouer'd had the raine,
Whom thus recouer'd by wise Patience,
But soone as she her sence recouer'd had,
Till he recouered had his former hew:
Till he recouered had his late decayed plight.
Till by his death he it recouered;
Could scarce recouered be out of her paine;
But soone as life recouered had the raine,
Now well recouered after long repast,
That ere him selfe he had recouered well,
Tho when they both recouered were right well,
But when againe they had recouered sence,
That they to life recouered her at last.
He falleth nigh to ground, and scarse recouereth flight.
At last recouering hart, he does begin
Himselfe recouering, was return'd to fight;
The gentle Squire recouers grace,
From whence ere he recouery could gaine,
Then shall I you recount a ruefull cace,
Of my most dreaded Soueraigne I recount,
Begin, ï¿½ Clio, and recount from hence
That shall I you recount (quoth he) ywis,
Ye will recount to vs in order dew
In order as they came, could I recount them well.
Cannot recount, nor tell their hidden race,
Then to recount the Seas posterity:
Yet all those same were there, which erst I did recount.
True vertue to aduance, shall here recounted bee.
She vnto him recounted, all that fell:
Now with recounting of like former breaches
Whence ere he could recou'r, he did him quell,
Eftsoones the others did the field recoure,
Then Cerberus, when Orpheus did recoure
The Briton Prince recou'ring his stolne sword,
Her crased health, her late recourse to rest,
That by the swift recourse of flushing blood
As to his memory they had recourse:
As well as to her minde it had recourse.
Full lightly, ere himselfe he could recower,
But th'idle stroke yet backe recoyld in vaine,
But backe againe the sparckling steele recoyld,
Iread you rest, and to your bowres recoyle.
But neither toyle nor trauell might her backe recoyle.
Ere to his den he backward could recoyle,
Commaunded him from slaughter to recoyle,
That forst him backe recoyle, and reele areare;
As he recoyled backward, in the mire
Of reasons rule, to see this recreant knight,
Thou recreant knight, and soone thy selfe prepaire
Lo recreant (sayd he) the fruitlesse end
Thou recreant false traytor, that with lone
And counted but a recreant Knight, with endles shame.
Vile recreant, know that I doe much disdaine
And neuer to be recreant, for feare
And be for euer held a recreant Knight,
Atwene that Ladie myld and recreant knight,
That recreant knight, whose hated life I sought?
And to reuile, and rate, and recreant call,
Then taking vp that Recreants shield and speare,
And oft recuile to shunne his sharpe despight.
Backe to recule; vntill that yron man
And haue her strength recur'd from fraile infirmitis.
Right well recur'd, and did away that blame
Labour'd in vaine, to haue recur'd their prize,
By this he had sweete life recur'd againe,
She his hurt thigh to him recur'd againe,
And wearie limmes recur'd after late vsage bad.
Who when him selfe now well recur'd did see,
Conuay to be recur'd. She thankt him deare,
Their wounds recur'd, and forces reincreast,
In westerne waues his wearie wagon did recure.
It could recure, and aged long decay
That mote recure their wounds: so inly they did tine.
His foot thereon, may neuer it recure,
Which wrought it, could the same recure againe.
And if I hap to fayle, you shall recure my right.
But ere his hand he could recure againe,
But ere he could him selfe recure againe,
Who then can thinke their hedlong ruine to recure.
Her to recure out of that stony swound,
Which to recure, no skill of Leaches art
With dew repast they had recured well,
By which to ease he him recured briefe,
I him recured to a better will,
Being at last recured, he gan inquire,
Restord, and sory wounds right well recured,
Yet euermore his honour he recured,
Till she recured were of those her woundes wide.
Recured well, and made him whole againe:
After that Timias had againe recured
It euer can recured be againe;
A goodly Lady clad in scarlot red,
The red bloud trickling staind the way, as he did ride.
That much was worne, but therein little red,
His eyes did hurle forth sparkles fiery red,
And heathnish shield, wherein with letters red
That in his armour bare a croslet red.
To tell the sad sight, which mine eies haue red:
From flaming mouth bright sparkles fierie red,
Whose kingdomes seat Cleopolis is red,
And said, Old sire, it seemes thou hast not red
Each bone might through his body well be red,
That hast my name and nation red aright,
Bespotted all with shields of red and blacke,
Loaden with fruit and apples rosie red,
Whereof great vertues ouer all were red:
With rosie cheekes, for shame as blushing red;
Which he disclosing, red thus, as the paper spake.
When he these bitter byting words had red,
That of the world least part to vs is red:
And playnd of grieuous outrage, which he red
His ruddie lips did smile, and rosy red
And in her cheekes the vermeill red did shew
All good and honour might therein be red:
His steed was bloudy red, and fomed ire,
Deepe in his flesh, and opened wide a red floodgate.
His pricking armes, entrayld with roses red,
Of PhÃ¦dria (for so my name is red)
With hearbs and fruits, whose kinds mote not be red:
In whose dead face he red great magnanimity.
Out of the wound the red bloud flowed fresh,
Als when his brother saw the red bloud rayle
Red as the Rose, thence gushed grieuously;
At th'upper end there sate, yclad in red
And euer and anone with rosie red
So long they red in those antiquities,
But shame and sad reproch, here to be red,
Are deckt with blossomes dyde in white and red,
Be red; that euer open stood to all,
Some as the Rubine, laughing sweetly red,
But the sage wisard telles, as he has red,
And rich purueyance might vneath be red;
And euer and anone the rosy red,
But who does wonder, that has red the Towre,
Spoild of their rosie red, were woxen pale and wan.
She bath'd with roses red, and violets blew,
And of her selfe her name Belphoebe red:
Whose sides empurpled were with smiling red,
With breathed flames, like to a furnace red,
But in his eye his meaning wisely red,
Which well she red out of the learned line,
She proud of that new honour, which they red,
Who with Sir Satyrane, as earst ye red,
That dyde in sanguine red her skin all snowy cleene.
He red, and measur'd many a sad verse,
And all the while he red, she did extend
That by her monstrous shape might easily be red.
Of beasts, or of the earth, I haue not red:
That who he whilome was, vneath was to be red.
Here well I weene, when as these rimes be red
Which when I red, my heart did inly earne,
And wondrous sholes, which may of none be red.
Which loue he red to be, that leads each liuing kind.
And if then those may any worse be red,
Whose like before she neuer saw nor red;
The fruitfull vine, whose liquor blouddy red
Her linnen stole to robe of scarlet red,
Or what so penaunce shall by you be red.
So now Malfont was plainely to be red;
Nor of ought else, that may be richest red,
That many high regards and reasons gainst her red.
That he had red her Riddle, which no wight
And all her bones might through her cheekes be red;
So taking counsell of a wise man red,
That plainely may in this wyld man be red,
And saluage with their bloud fresh steeming red,
It fortun'd then, that when the roules were red,
Both of his words, which he with reason red;
The Redcrosse Knight from Truth:
The knight of the Redcrosse when him he spide,
And saw the Red-crosse, which the knight did beare,
That doth this Redcrosse knights ensample plainly proue.
But she all vowd vnto the Redcrosse knight,
Or tydings of her knight of the Redcrosse.
What more? the Redcrosse knight was slaine with Paynim knife.
That good knight of the Redcrosse to haue slain:
That Redcrosse knight, perdie, I neuer slew,
The Redcrosse knight is captiue made
Where she had left, the noble Redcrosse knight,
Then she did loue the knight of the Redcrosse;
O heauie record of the good Redcrosse,
Else should this Redcrosse knight in bands haue dyde,
Whom Redcrosse knight withstands.
As this good Prince redeemd the Redcrosse knight from bands.
Thine, O then, said the gentle Redcrosse knight,
Which to requite, the Redcrosse knight him gaue
The Redcrosse knight toward him crossed fast,
When as the gentle Redcrosse knight did vew,
That made the Redcrosse knight nigh quake for feare,
Faire Vna to the Redcrosse knight
To whom the Redcrosse knight this answere sent,
The Redcrosse knight awaytes,
Soone as the Redcrosse knight he vnderstands,
To see the Redcrosse thus aduaunced hye;
Then said the Redcrosse knight, Now mote I weet,
Palmer, (him answered the Redcrosse knight)
For since the Redcrosse knight he earst did weet,
By Guyon, and by that false Redcrosse knight,
The Redcrosse Knight was soone disarmed there,
And eke the Redcrosse knight ran to the stownd,
And eke the Redcrosse knight gaue her good aid,
The Redcrosse knight to Britomart
All which the Redcrosse knight to point ared,
Where meeting with this Redcrosse knight, she fond
The Redcrosse knight diuerst, but forth rode Britomart.
Who when through speaches with the Redcrosse knight,
By which the Redcrosse knight did earst display
By a good knight, the knight of the Redcrosse;
But somewhat redder, then beseem'd aright,
He hath his shield redeem'd, and foorth his sword he drawes.
As this good Prince redeemd the Redcrosse knight from bands.
And soone redeeme from his long wandring woe;
That he my captiue langour should redeeme,
Faire virgin to redeeme her deare
That to redeeme thy woefull parents head,
And captiues to redeeme with price of bras,
Ne worldly price cannot redeeme my deare,
Out of his hands could not redeeme her gage,
I yearned haue, that life so dearely did redeeme.
She you from death, you me from dread redeemed.
When her from deadly thraldome he redeemed,
By Braggadochio lately was redeemed.
Till he redeemed had that Lady thrall:
Of the blynd boy, ne thence could be redeemed
And his redeemer chalengd for his foe,
The sacred badge of my Redeemers death,
His deare Redeemers badge vpon the bosse:
Whence Britomart redeemes faire
Her Calidore from them redeemes,
Sith no redemption nigh she did nor heare nor see.
His borrowed waters forst to redisbourse,
Therewith redoubled was his raging yre,
But that redoubled crime with vengeance new
But with redoubled buffes them backe did put:
And doubling all his powres, redoubled euery stroke.
Weake body well is chang'd for minds redoubled forse.
With huge redoubled strokes she on him layd;
His stroke redoubled with such might and maine,
A second fall redoubling backe againe.
Her doubtfull words made that redoubted knight
Redoubted battaile ready to darrayne,
There to obtaine some such redoubted knight,
Redoubted knight, that for mine onely sake
To be the shield of some redoubted knight;
He was a man of rare redoubted might,
Vnworthy vsage of redoubted knight.
Renowmed Martia, and redoubted Emmilen.
Redoubted knights, and honorable Dames,
That bold he said; ï¿½ most redoubted Pere,
That dread thereof, and his redoubted might
At last the most redoubted Britonesse,
Into redoubted perill forth did call;
The sixt was Lansack, a redoubted Knight:
Him thus bespake; O most redoubted Knight
Trew sacred lore, which from her sweet lips did redound.
Ay doing things, that to his fame redound,
Of hurt vnwist most daunger doth redound:
A pound of gall doth ouer it redound.
And softly royne, when saluage choler gan redound.
Right so in Faery court it did redound,
But all that day the greatest prayse redounded
Redounding teares did choke th'end of her plaint,
For that Hippolytus rent corse he did redresse.
Whereof he crau'd redresse. My Soueraine,
Eftsoones deuisd redresse for such annoyes;
Him stayd from yielding pitifull redresse;
His single speare could doe him small redresse,
Yet no'te she find redresse for such despight.
Redresse the wrong of miserable wight,
Of his loues succour, of his owne redresse,
But if the heauens helpe to redresse her wrong,
If heauen, then none may it redresse or blame,
Ye may redresse, and me restore to light.
Her to redresse: but since he meanes found none
She her besought of gratious redresse.
And wrong redresse in such as wend awry.
In which he swam, and ranne to his redresse.
Both to redresse, and both redrest likewise:
And sent redresse thereof by this braue Briton Knight.
A Dragons taile, whose sting without redresse
In which he was that Realme for to redresse.
He saw, the present mischiefe to redresse,
Which could redresse, for it was inwardly vnsound.
Which to redresse, she did th'assistance need
Would for it selfe redresse, and punish such despights.
Cannot redressed be by liuing wight.
For all I seeke, is but to haue redrest
Or other learned meanes could haue redrest
That shortly she his dolour hath redrest,
What boots it plaine, that cannot be redrest,
What boots it then to plaine, that cannot be redrest?
And thought his wearie limbs to haue redrest.
That in short space his hurts he had redrest,
To let her die, whom he might haue redrest.
Both to redresse, and both redrest likewise:
That hauing there their wounds awhile redrest,
For dread of daunger, not to be redrest,
Shall to the same reduce, and to him call
And all things would reduce vnto equality.
He could enforme, and them reduce aright,
Till it reduced was to one mans gouernments.
And his foule sore reduced to faire plight:
It she reduced, but himselfe destroyed quight.
Whose countreis he redus'd to quiet state,
A paire of redwhot yron tongs did take
That through the wood reecchoed againe,
Such vgly monstrous shapes elswhere may no man reed.
My crime, (if crime it be) I will it reed.
And on a broken reed he still did stay
That mongst the manie vertues, which we reed,
A straunger knight, from whence no man could reed,
Concord she cleeped was in common reed,
Long had the Thames (as we in records reed)
But not that arme, nor thou the man I reed,
As when a skilfull Marriner doth reed
Perdy thou peasant Knight, mightst rightly reed
Of this her groome, which he by signes did reede;
With holesome reede of sad sobriety,
Which fame of her shrill trompet worthy reedes:
A little cottage, built of stickes and reedes
For trumpets sterne to chaunge mine Oaten reeds,
Reeking aloft, vprolled to the sky:
Whiles yet his feeble feet for faintnesse reeld,
But too and fro in great amazement reel'd,
And Sisyphus an huge round stone did reele
That made him reele, and to his brest his beuer bent.
That horse and man it made to reele aside;
Yet made him twise to reele, that neuer moou'd afore.
And feeble spirits, that gan faint and reele,
That forst him backe recoyle, and reele areare;
That twise he reeled, readie twise to fall;
But reeled to and fro from East to West:
And feeble spirit inly felt refection;
That feeles the warmth of sunny beames reflection,
Had it defaste; thenceforth reformd her waies,
And better to reforme, then to cut off the ill.
How to reforme that ragged common-weale:
But ere he could reforme it thoroughly,
Whilest he reformed that vnciuill fo:
And wicked customes of that Bridge refourmed.
I gan refraine, in minde to slip away,
Commaunded them their fury to refraine,
So strongly, that vneathes it can refraine
She oft and oft aduiz'd him to refraine
From loue in course of nature to refraine:
That the hard rocks could scarse from teares refraine,
Staid not to answer, scarcely did refraine,
That forced them from fighting to refraine,
That all brute beasts forst to refraine fro meat,
For they for nought would from their worke refraine,
That it his ranging fancie did refraine,
Then either care of parents could refraine,
Her tender heart, and made refraine from meat,
But nathemore would they from land refraine,
Ne would he spare for pitty, nor refraine for feare.
And did him selfe from fraile impatience refraine.
Albe the wyld-man hardly would refraine.
First learne your outward sences to refraine
Euen stout Sans foy (O who can then refrayn?)
Him from his wicked will vneath refrayned;
With heauie eyne, from teares vneath refrayning,
That the drie withered stocke it gan refresh,
Him to refresh, and her late wounds to heale:
And oft refreshed, battell oft renue:
Himselfe refreshing with the liquid cold,
And bodies were refresht with due repast,
Haue reft away with his sharpe rending clawes:
That him of life, and vs of ioy hath reft?
Me reft from it, had bene partaker of the place.
His powre is reft, and weaknesse doth remaine.
From thence a Faerie thee vnweeting reft,
Himselfe thereby reft of his sences meet,
Then when as vse of speach was from her reft,
So that faire spectacle from him was reft,
Yet that, which reft it, no lesse faire was fownd:
And reft from men the worlds desired vew,
Now lyest thou of life and honor reft;
And cursed night, that reft from him so goodly scope.
And fro me reft both life and light attone.
Which reft from him so faire a cheuisaunce:
Which hath thy Lady reft, and knighthood shent,
From whom the Squire of Dames was reft whylere;
He that from Braggadocchio whilome reft
Out of his headpeece Cambell fiercely reft,
That from his shoulders quite his head he reft:
For notwithstanding that one soule was reft,
How hauing reft her from the witches sonne,
Some thought from him her to haue reft by might;
The fayrest Ladie reft, and euer since withheld.
For lately he my loue hath fro me reft,
What is of her become, or whether reft,
With ready hand it to haue reft away.
And shew'd that she had not that Lady reft,
Of all her louers, which would her haue reft.
Fro me reft mine away by lawlesse might,
But Florimells owne girdle, from her reft,
Then from him reft his shield, and it renuerst,
Which had bene reft from many a noble Knight;
Ere all her children he from her had reft.
He lightly reft his head, to ease him of his paine.
For to pursue that villaine, which had reft
Of a discourteous Knight, who her had reft,
And his Loue reft away, he wexed wood,
The selfe same flocks, the which those theeues had reft
Had reft from Meliboe, and from his make,
To find some refuge there, and rest her weary syde.
For refuge from the Monsters crueltie,
He was compeld to seeke some refuge neare,
His hope of refuge vsed to remaine.
But his best succour and refuge was still
Hoping vnto some refuge to withdraw:
How that straunge sword refusd, to serue his need,
For that their tribute he refusd to let be payd.
Yet flat refusd to haue a do with mee,
For flatly he of entrance was refusd,
So much the more as she refusd to loue,
That for her sake refus'd to enterprize
As was my friend, that had her long refusd,
Yet he them all refusd, though thankt her as a frend.
Yet had refusde a God that her had sought to wife.
She in regard hereof refusde and thought vnfit.
Will die for thirst, and water doth refuse?
Refuse such fruitlesse toile, and present pleasures chuse.
If thee list not, leaue haue thou to refuse:
That all thine idle offers I refuse.
Ne let his fairest Cynthia refuse,
Would me refuse their pledges to afford,
Though nought beleu'd, & entrau[n]ce late did not refuse.
To turne she doth refuse.
Whom when the rest did see her to refuse,
For time yet serues that I the same refuse,
That all her piteous plaint they did refuse,
Nor that thing worst, which men do most refuse;
That for his loue refused deitie;
But when she saw her offred sweets refused
But thing refused, do not afterward accuse.
That he so wilfully refused grace;
The first which then refused me (said hee)
But euermore she him refused flat,
But she it all refused at one word,
Refused hath to yeeld her loue againe,
